dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey everyone, and welcome back to the podcast! Today, we're diving into something super crucial for, well, success in general: negotiation preparation. It’s not just about showing up, right Host_B?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey everyone, and welcome back to the podcast! Today, we're diving into something super crucial for, well, success in general: negotiation preparation. It's not just about showing up, right Host_B?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely, Host_A! The article really hammers home that first point: identifying your goals and objectives. It sounds simple, but, uh, apparently, experts say it accounts for like, five percent of your success.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely, Host_A! The article really hammers home that first point: identifying your goals and objectives. It sounds simple, but, uh, apparently, experts say it accounts for like, five percent of your success.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Effectively identifying your goals and objectives is seemingly a simple step but many experts suggest it accounts for 50% of your success.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Five percent! That's huge. And it’s not just about direct gains or profits, is it? You gotta factor in your business environment, the cultural perceptions around you...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Five percent! That's huge. And it's not just about direct gains or profits, is it? You gotta factor in your business environment, the cultural perceptions around you...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These are imperative, but equally vital are your business and life environment as well as the cultural perceptions and expectations of the people around you.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, and whether it’s a one-time thing or the start of a long-term collaboration. That completely changes how you, you know, approach it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and whether it's a one-time thing or the start of a long-term collaboration. That completely changes how you, you know, approach it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Is this a one-time engagement or the beginning of the long road of a collaboration process, which will grow in value over time? This will help you see a bigger picture and develop a better strategy!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Then, information! The article states, "information is power." It doesn't matter if it's a small or big negotiation; it's the fuel.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Then, information! The article states, information is power. It doesn't matter if it's a small or big negotiation; it's the fuel.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Information is power! Small or big negotiations, it doesnt matter information is the fuel of your success in moving towards your goals and objectives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: For sure! Like, using the 5W1H framework – who, what, when, where, why, and how. And, uh, with modern ICTs, you can dig up so much online, Google, Twitter, everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure! Like, using the five W one hours framework - who, what, when, where, why, and how. And, uh, with modern I C T s, you can dig up so much online, Google, Twitter, everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thus, it is important to prepare well by collecting and analyzing information using a classic MBA formula for business background research and problem solving: 5W or 5W1H (who, what, when, where, why and how). Modern Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs) provide great tools for information gathering including general business data in databanks and information about counterparts on LinkedIn, Facebook, etc.).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And then, the classic: SWOT analysis. Strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, threats. It's not just for *your* side, though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then, the classic: S W O T analysis. Strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, threats. It's not just for your side, though.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is especially useful if you run one SWOT assessing your own position, and run the second SWOT for understanding the strengths and weaknesses of the other side of the table.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No! The article suggests doing one for yourself, and then a *second* one for the other side. That's just, like, smart strategy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No! The article suggests doing one for yourself, and then a second one for the other side. That's just, like, smart strategy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is especially useful if you run one SWOT assessing your own position, and run the second SWOT for understanding the strengths and weaknesses of the other side of the table.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Super smart. And that leads right into choosing your negotiation tactics and strategy. Thinking about your end goals, and laying out the steps.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Super smart. And that leads right into choosing your negotiation tactics and strategy. Thinking about your end goals, and laying out the steps.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Strategic vision of the negotiation process and your end-goals and objectives should be backed up with carefully thought-out and appropriate tactics. This stage of preparation allows you to lay out the sequence of tactical steps that will allow you to best position yourself during the actual negotiations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, and having an acceptable "walk-away alternative." I mean, you don't wanna be so desperate that you sign an abysmal agreement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, and having an acceptable walk-away alternative. I mean, you don't wanna be so desperate that you sign an abysmal agreement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Experts even suggest developing an acceptable walk-away alternative in order not to get so desperate that you sign an abysmal deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Oh, absolutely. That’s probably one of the biggest takeaways for me. And then, pre-meeting questions! How many times have we heard, "I forgot to ask that!"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. That's probably one of the biggest takeaways for me. And then, pre-meeting questions! How many times have we heard, I forgot to ask that!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Every time, right? The article says at least eight questions. And, uh, it helps you identify "red herrings" – issues that mean nothing to you but might be huge for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Every time, right? The article says at least eight questions. And, uh, it helps you identify red herrings - issues that mean nothing to you but might be huge for them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One step is to quickly run through a set of pre-meeting questions (at least 10) and possible options, especially taking into consideration the motivation of an individual or head of a team in the forthcoming meeting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Super clever. Then, settling the agenda. A clear, mutually agreed agenda right from the start.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Super clever. Then, settling the agenda. A clear, mutually agreed agenda right from the start.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, all textbook examples of successful negotiations suggest that it is crucial to set up a clear and mutually agreed agenda right at the beginning, with a sequence of negotiation steps, and to clarify expected outcomes (e.g., signing a deal).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, that helps clarify expected outcomes. And finally, engaging with confidence and respect. The psychological dimension is, um, really important.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep, that helps clarify expected outcomes. And finally, engaging with confidence and respect. The psychological dimension is, um, really important.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The psychological dimension of negotiation meetings makes a surprisingly big impact on the negotiation process and outcomes...engaging in the bargaining process with full confidence as well as full respect for the person or a team across the table.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. Even in business, where we expect rational people, being cool-headed, professional, and respectful can make a huge difference.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. Even in business, where we expect rational people, being cool-headed, professional, and respectful can make a huge difference.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The psychological dimension of negotiation meetings makes a surprisingly big impact on the negotiation process and outcomes, even though in the business setting we expect to see extremely rational people with rational approaches. Therefore, successful negotiation includes showing your cool-headed professionalism...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, really, it all boils down to being incredibly well-prepared, understanding all the angles, and, uh, even building your own personal archive of past negotiations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, really, it all boils down to being incredibly well-prepared, understanding all the angles, and, uh, even building your own personal archive of past negotiations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: it is important to establish your own style and approach to the negotiation process by creating your personal archive with a set of notes or databank about every successful negotiation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: What a great way to put it, Host_B. It's about ongoing learning and preparation! Thanks for joining us, everyone!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What a great way to put it, Host_B. It's about ongoing learning and preparation! Thanks for joining us, everyone!
